questions.question_text: Which of the following should be configured on the network to achieve performance for the FCoE storage traffic?

discussion.content:
Instead of using an older technology and trying to adhere to legacy standards,
Fibre Channel (FC) is an option providing a higher level of performance than
anything else. It utilizes FCP, the Fiber Channel Protocol, to do what needs to be
done, and Fiber Channel over Ethernet (FCoE) can be used in high-speed (10
GB and higher) implementations.
The big advantage of Fibre Channel is its scalability. FCoE encapsulates FC over
the Ethernet portions of connectivity, making it easy to add into an existing
network. As such, FCoE is an extension to FC intended to extend the scalability
and efficiency associated with Fibre Channel.

Key is in the question "narrow scope" and "class C". This eliminates all choices apart from ones that start with 192. Now that is the class C. For the narrow scope we want fewest available amount of ip addresses which is a /30. So given answer is correct

We deduce the class of an IP address from the number in the first octet, see below
[0-127].x.x.x - Class A
[128-191].x.x.x - Class B
[192-223].x.x.x - Class C
This makes C the only correct answer from the above options
Everything I have ever read says that Class C private address range is 192.168.0.0 – 192.168.255.255. Can anyone tell me how 192.1.0.124 is within that range?

comments.content: I think you're thinking about private addresses.
Class C is from 192.x.x.x to 223.x.x.x with subnet mask of 255.255.255.0. So C is correct for the question. This gives 4 ip address which only 2 are usable.

discussion.content:
It seems that correct answr is D. 192.168.0.192/24.
IP address range for class C is: from 192.168.0.0 to 192.168.255.255
C. 192.1.0.124/30 - it is out of range for class C.
D. 192.168.0.192/24 - correct answer.
E. 192.170.10.0/24 - it is out of range for class C.
Why is it C instead of A or B? All three are class C addresses.

comments.content:
10.x.x.x is Class A
172.x.x.x is Class B
192.x.x.x is Class C

questions.question_text: A network administrator wants to narrow the scope of a subnet to two usable IP addresses within a class C network. Which of the following is the correct CIDR notation?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C should be the correct answer, although we should add an NDA too. Hahaha
BYOB is the correct answer I believe

questions.question_text: Which of the following policies would Joe, a user, have to agree to when he brings in his personal tablet to connect to the company's guest wireless Internet?

choices.C: Some of the servers are configured to use different gateways.
choices.A: New servers are being provisioned in the cloud.
choices.D: Part of the subnet is configured to use different VLANs.

questions.question_text: A network technician notices that most of the nodes in the 10.10.74.0/23 address space return either 1 or 2 node hop after running a tracert; however, some of the new servers are showing a hop count larger than 10. Which of the following is the MOST likely reason for this?

discussion.content: Both A and C can be right, however assumed the servers are in the same company which probably don't use that many routers/gateway, so answer A makes more sense imo.
This is a dumb question that leave out important information to answer it properly.
The Key word was more than 10. unless its a monster of a company the path is most likely leaving the company network.
These types of questions are ridiculous. The best way to answer these is to not think to deep into them and select the most reasonable answer by process of elimination.

Why can’t it be ‘C’ ?
C. Some of the servers are configured to use different gateways.

questions.question_text: A technician has a remote site that often has congestion issues. When this happens, the remote router cannot be managed using SSH because the session drops. Which of the following is a possible solution to the issue?

discussion.content:
The correct answer is A. Out-of-band management.
More information: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LHHbPXAzRBs
I dont get this. Isn't he already using out-of-band management and it isnt working because the session drops?

comments.content: No, the question states the session starts dropping when the congestion occurs, implying the user is connecting via the existing problematic network connection.
SpacePeanut is correct yet the probability of Coconut and SpacePeanut is less than 0.02 percent of meeting each other in this scenario.
